Pulmonary aspergillosis can manifest with fever, cough, and respiratory distress but would be unlikely to cause calcified nodules, hilar lymphadenopathy, or the antigen findings seen in this case. In addition, biopsy of affected tissue would show acute-angle septate hyphae on staining, not intracellular organisms.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

There are numerous elongated, septated hyphae (examples indicated by blue overlay) of uniform diameter and with dichotomous branching at approx. 45° angles.

This is the typical appearance of Aspergillus. A culture is required to determine the exact Aspergillus species.

F) CORRECT:

Bat and bird droppings can carry Histoplasma capsulatum, particularly in endemic areas (e.g., the Ohio and Mississippi river valleys). Inhalation of the fungus causes histoplasmosis, a condition that manifests with primary pulmonary disease or disseminated disease, especially in patients who are immunocompromised.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue specimen (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Intracellular (examples indicated by white arrowheads) and extracellular (examples indicated by black arrowheads) forms of ovoid yeast-like organisms are visible.

The presence of these organisms is indicative of histoplasmosis. Diagnosis must be confirmed by culture and PCR array to determine the exact species (Histoplasma capsulatum in this case).
questions.hint: This woman has pneumonia (fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, cough, chest pain, crackles), hilar lymphadenopathy, a polysaccharide antigen in the urine, and a biopsy specimen of the lung that shows yeast cells within macrophages, all of which are features of Histoplasma capsulatum infection.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the military physician because of a 2-day history of fever, joint pain, dry cough, chest pain, and a painful red rash on her lower legs. Two weeks ago, she returned from military training in Southern California. She appears ill. Her temperature is 39°C (102.1°F). Physical examination shows diffuse inspiratory crackles over all lung fields and multiple tender erythematous nodules over the anterior aspect of both legs. A biopsy specimen of this patient's lungs is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Spherules filled with endospores on culture are a histological hallmark of coccidioidomycosis. Transmission of the disease is generally due to inhalation of fungal spores from contaminated soil. The disease typically presents with pneumonia and may also show extrapulmonary symptoms affecting the skin (desert bumps), CNS (meningitis), or joints (desert rheumatism).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E stain, medium power magnification)

A thick-walled spherule (yellow overlay) is visible near the center of an inflammatory granuloma (blue overlay). The spherule contains multiple endospores.

This histological appearance suggests pulmonary coccidioidomycosis. The diagnosis should be confirmed by culture and serological tests (IgM and IgG antibodies).

B) INCORRECT:

Non-septate hyphae with wide-angle branching is suggestive of Mucor and Rhizopus, two genera of molds that are ubiquitous in decaying vegetation and soil. Mucormycosis usually causes facial symptoms such as invasive chronic sinusitis, orbital cellulitis, or black necrotic eschar, but not pneumonia and erythematous nodules. Furthermore, it usually affects patients with diabetes mellitus and immunocompromised individuals.
Image Description:

Microscopy of heart valve tissues (Methenamine silver stain)

Long Ribbon-like structures can be observed (red overlay). They are wide and not septated.


These are the characteristic features of Mucor pusillus.

C) INCORRECT:

Broad-based budding yeast is characteristic of blastomycosis, a fungal infection caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, which typically causes pneumonia and skin lesions (verrucous lesions, granulomatous nodules) similar to the findings in this patient. However, this fungus is endemic to the Southeastern and Central US, the Midwest, and Canadian states near the Great Lakes, not to Southern California.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (PAS stain)

Two large cells with thick walls are visible in the center of the image (green overlay). There is a single, broad-based area of contact between the two cells. These are budding Blastomyces dermatitidis yeast cells. The yeast cells are surrounded by numerous neutrophils.

Thick-walled fungi with single, broad-based buds are characteristic features of the yeast form of Blastomyces dermatitidis at body temperature (37°C). At room temperature (∼23°C), Blastomyces dermatitidis exists in a mold form.

D) INCORRECT:

Oval, budding yeast with pseudohyphae is characteristic of Candida, a type of yeast (fungus) that appears almost universally in low numbers on healthy skin and mucosa as a commensal organism. Candida usually causes oral thrush, candida esophagitis, or vaginal yeast infection in immunocompromised individuals. Pneumonia or erythematous nodules would not be expected.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of fungus germination (KOH preparation, 600x)

Mother cells (blastospores; green overlay) produce a hyphal outgrowth of germ tubes (budding; dashed red outline).

Budding is suggestive of active candida infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Septate hyphae with acute-angle branching is characteristic of Aspergillus, a ubiquitous genus of fungus. Aspergillus can cause pneumonia. However, it usually affects patients who are immunocompromised or susceptible to infection due to preexisting conditions (e.g. tuberculosis). Moreover, erythematous nodules would not be expected.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Aspergillus fumigatus

Several buds are visible sprouting from the thread-like structure of the septate hyphae (green overlays). Buds are composed of a stalk (conidiophore; blue overlay) topped by a conidial head. The head consists of a central spherical vesicle (not visible here but indicated by yellow circle) surrounded by chains of prophialide (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and phialide projections (examples indicated by green arrowheads) with conidia tips (examples indicated by black arrowheads). The base is formed by a foot cell (red overlay).

F) INCORRECT:

Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells is characteristic of paracoccidioidomycosis, a fungal infection caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, which is most commonly found in Central and South America but not in southwestern parts of the US. Infected patients may present with pneumonia and verrucous skin lesions but usually do not develop symptoms.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue sample stained for fungi (methenamine silver stain)

Multiple large, round yeast cells are present. On some of the cells, narrow-necked budding can be seen, resulting in the characteristic “captain's wheel” formation (illustration; example indicated by green overlay).

This is the typical appearance of the budding yeasts causing paracoccidioidomycosis.
questions.hint: This patient's features of acute pneumonia (dry cough, chest pain, fever), arthralgia, and tender erythematous nodules should raise concern for infection with Coccidioides, a pathogenic fungus endemic to the southwestern parts of the United States.

questions.text: An investigator is studying growth patterns of various fungal pathogens. Incubation of an isolated fungus at 25°C shows branching hyphae with rosettes of conidia under light microscopy. After incubation at 37°C, microscopic examination of the same organism instead shows smooth, white colonies with rounded, elongated cells. Infection with the investigated pathogen is most likely to cause which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcosis is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, a yeast with a thick polysaccharide capsule and narrow, unequal budding. It is not dimorphic and has no hyphal form. Microscopic diagnosis of this fungus can be made with specialized stains, such as mucicarmine, that bind the polysaccharide capsule.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

B) INCORRECT:

Aspergillosis is caused by fungi of the genus Aspergillus, none of which are a dimorphic fungus. Regardless of the incubating temperature, microscopy would reveal septate hyphae branching at 45° and conidia in radiating chains. Yeast forms would not be seen.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

There are numerous elongated, septated hyphae (examples indicated by blue overlay) of uniform diameter and with dichotomous branching at approx. 45° angles.

This is the typical appearance of Aspergillus. A culture is required to determine the exact Aspergillus species.

C) INCORRECT:

Candidiasis is caused by the dimorphic fungus Candida albicans, which appears as a budding yeast with pseudohyphae when cultured at 20°C. Septated and branching hyphae, oval conidia, and cigar-shaped yeast forms are not characteristic of C. albicans.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (200x magnification)

A cluster of yeast-like cells (arrowhead) is visible in the upper right corner of the image. Arising from this cluster are numerous pseudohyphae identifiable as long filamentous nonseptate structures (example indicated by a blue overlay). Asexual budding spores (blastospores; example indicated by red overlay) arise along the sides of the pseudohyphae. Thick-walled solitary circular chlamydospores (resting stage of Candida; example indicated by green overlay) arise from the tips of the pseudohyphae.

This coexistence of different morphological types (yeast cells, pseudohyphae, budding blastospores, and resting chlamydospores) is typical of Candida albicans.

D) INCORRECT:

Coccidiomycosis is caused by Coccidioides, a dimorphic fungus that may also grow with septated hyphae. Instead of smooth, white colonies with rounded, elongated cells, the characteristic microscopic finding is a spherule filled with endospores of Coccidioides.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Coccidioides immitis in lung tissue (methenamine silver stain; high magnification)

Spherule (red circles) and endospore (green overlays) forms of Coccidioides immitis, a causative agent of coccidioidomycosis, can be seen.

E) CORRECT:

Sporothrix schenckii, which causes sporotrichosis, is most likely the fungus in question. As a dimorphic fungus, Sporothrix exists in yeast or hyphal forms depending on the surrounding temperature. At 25°C, it takes on its hyphal form, with septate branching hyphae and oval conidia. Clusters of these conidia may appear as rosettes. However, when grown at 37°C, microscopic evaluation reveals a cigar-shaped budding yeast. The fungus feeds on decaying plants and Infection occurs after a penetrating skin injury, e.g., from a thorn prick, explaining its prevalence in gardeners and similar workers. Sporotrichosis initially manifests as a pustule or ulcer that progresses to ascending lymphangitis.
Image Description:

Microscopy of a fungal culture at 25°C (lactophenol cotton blue stain)
Culture specimen obtained from a skin ulcer.

Numerous septated hyphae are seen.
Oval spores (conidia) are connected to the hyphae with narrow stems.
The buds are arranged in rosette-like clusters at the tips of the hyphae.

This is the typical appearance of the mold (mycelial) form of the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.
(At body temperature or temperatures > 37°C, Sporothrix schenckii exists in a yeast form, with characteristic cigar-shaped yeast cells.)
questions.hint: The isolated organism exhibits fungal dimorphism. One of the characteristic clinical features in infected patients is ascending lymphangitis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with a history of cystic fibrosis is brought to the physician for evaluation of recurrent episodes of productive cough, wheezing, and shortness of breath over the past month. Physical examination shows coarse crackles and expiratory wheezing over both lung fields. Serum studies show elevated levels of IgE and eosinophilia. A CT scan of the lungs shows centrally dilated bronchi with thickened walls and peripheral airspace consolidation. Antibiotic therapy is initiated. One week later, the patient continues to show deterioration in lung function. A sputum culture is most likely to grow which of the following?

choices.text: Monomorphic, septate hyphae that branch at acute angles
Monomorphic, broad, nonseptate hyphae that branch at wide angles

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dimorphic, broad-based budding yeasts are characteristic of Blastomyces dermatitidis, which causes blastomycosis. In immunocompetent individuals, blastomycosis typically manifests as acute or chronic pneumonia and, especially in immunocompromised individuals, extrapulmonary symptoms (e.g., verrucous skin and lytic bone lesions). Blastomycosis is not typically associated with cystic fibrosis. Furthermore, this patient's bronchiectasis, eosinophilia, and elevated serum IgE levels are not consistent with Blastomyces dermatitidis infection.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (PAS stain)

Two large cells with thick walls are visible in the center of the image (green overlay). There is a single, broad-based area of contact between the two cells. These are budding Blastomyces dermatitidis yeast cells. The yeast cells are surrounded by numerous neutrophils.

Thick-walled fungi with single, broad-based buds are characteristic features of the yeast form of Blastomyces dermatitidis at body temperature (37°C). At room temperature (∼23°C), Blastomyces dermatitidis exists in a mold form.

B) CORRECT:

Monomorphic, septate hyphae branching at acute angles are characteristic of Aspergillus fumigatus, the causative organism in allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. ABPA most commonly affects patients with cystic fibrosis or severe asthma. Small and ubiquitous spores of Aspergillus easily reach the alveoli where they trigger a chronic and complex hypersensitivity reaction, primarily due to poor mucociliary clearance. Symptoms of ABPA include wheezing, chronic cough, and shortness of breath. Imaging most often shows evidence of central bronchiectasis, as seen in this patient. ABPA is treated with glucocorticoids and itraconazole.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

There are numerous elongated, septated hyphae (examples indicated by blue overlay) of uniform diameter and with dichotomous branching at approx. 45° angles.

This is the typical appearance of Aspergillus. A culture is required to determine the exact Aspergillus species.

C) INCORRECT:

Dimorphic, cigar-shaped budding yeast may be seen in tissue samples from patients infected with Sporothrix schenckii, which causes sporotrichosis. Sporotrichosis most often presents as an ulcer at the site of recent skin trauma (classically, a prick from a rose thorn) that progresses to ascending lymphangitis. Pulmonary sporotrichosis is exceedingly rare and manifests as single or multiple cavitary lesions in immunocompromised patients. Bronchiectasis, eosinophilia, and elevated serum IgE levels would not be expected.
Image Description:

Microscopy of a fungal culture at 25°C (lactophenol cotton blue stain)
Culture specimen obtained from a skin ulcer.

Numerous septated hyphae are seen.
Oval spores (conidia) are connected to the hyphae with narrow stems.
The buds are arranged in rosette-like clusters at the tips of the hyphae.

This is the typical appearance of the mold (mycelial) form of the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.
(At body temperature or temperatures > 37°C, Sporothrix schenckii exists in a yeast form, with characteristic cigar-shaped yeast cells.)

D) INCORRECT:

Monomorphic, narrow budding encapsulated yeast are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans, a pathogenic fungus that can cause pneumonia in immunodeficient patients (e.g., those with AIDS). Cryptococcosis would be very unusual in a pediatric patient with cystic fibrosis. Furthermore, bronchiectasis, eosinophilia, and elevated serum IgE levels would not be expected.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

E) INCORRECT:

Monomorphic, broad, nonseptate hyphae that branch at wide angles are characteristic of Mucor and/or Rhizopus, two genera of molds that are ubiquitous in decaying vegetation and soil. The classic presentation of infection with these organisms is a rapidly progressive, necrotizing infection of the nose and face in a diabetic patient. Pulmonary mucormycosis is also possible and manifests in immunocompromised individuals with symptoms of pneumonia. Imaging may show a solitary nodule, cavitary lesion, or an area of consolidation but not bronchiectasis. Furthermore, elevated serum levels of IgE and eosinophilia would not be expected.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a maxillary sinus biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Broad, nonseptate hyphae with right-angle branching are visible (example indicated by green overlay). These are accompanied by numerous neutrophils indicating acute sinusitis.

This is the typical appearance of mucormycosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Dimorphic, budding yeast with pseudohyphae are microscopic features of candidiasis, which is caused by the fungus Candida albicans. Candidiasis can lead to pneumonia in immunocompromised patients, manifesting with fever, malaise, dyspnea, and cough. The central bronchiectasis (centrally dilated bronchi with thickened walls and peripheral airspace consolidation) seen on this patient's chest imaging, eosinophilia, and elevated levels of serum IgE are not typical of pulmonary candidiasis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (200x magnification)

A cluster of yeast-like cells (arrowhead) is visible in the upper right corner of the image. Arising from this cluster are numerous pseudohyphae identifiable as long filamentous nonseptate structures (example indicated by a blue overlay). Asexual budding spores (blastospores; example indicated by red overlay) arise along the sides of the pseudohyphae. Thick-walled solitary circular chlamydospores (resting stage of Candida; example indicated by green overlay) arise from the tips of the pseudohyphae.

This coexistence of different morphological types (yeast cells, pseudohyphae, budding blastospores, and resting chlamydospores) is typical of Candida albicans.
questions.hint: Failure to respond to antibiotic treatment in a patient with a history of cystic fibrosis, recurrent pulmonary exacerbations, elevated IgE levels, and CT findings of bronchiectasis should raise concern for allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with HIV infection is brought to the emergency department by his roommate because of a 2-week history of progressively worsening headache and vomiting. Current medications include trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, dolutegravir, and tenofovir-emtricitabine. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Physical examination shows nuchal rigidity. Kernig and Brudzinski signs are present. A lumbar puncture is performed and shows an opening pressure of 32 cm H2O (N: < 20). The pathogen isolated from the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) can be cultured on Sabouraud agar. Further evaluation of this patient's CSF is most likely to show which of the following additional findings?

choices.text: Positive PCR for JC virus DNA

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The presence of gram-positive diplococci in the CSF is seen in patients with bacterial meningitis caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is the most common causal bacterial pathogen of meningitis among adults of all ages. S. pneumoniae meningitis causes progressive headache, nausea, fever, meningism, and a significantly increased opening pressure on lumbar puncture. However, this condition typically manifests acutely over hours to days and would be an unlikely diagnosis for this patient whose symptoms have progressed across 2 weeks. In addition, S. pneumoniae cannot grow on Sabouraud agar; this organism can be cultured on bacterial media such as blood agar.

B) CORRECT:

The detection of cryptococcal antigen in the CSF by a latex agglutination test is highly sensitive for a diagnosis of cryptococcal meningoencephalitis. Like several other fungi, Cryptococcus spp. can grow on Sabouraud agar. Staining techniques also aid in the identification of this pathogen; India ink staining shows encapsulated yeast surrounded by clear halos, and mucicarmine staining shows yeast with a red inner capsule.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

C) INCORRECT:

A positive PCR for HSV-2 DNA in the CSF is seen in patients with herpes simplex meningitis. This condition can manifest with progressive headache, nausea, fever, and meningism. However, the opening pressure on lumbar puncture of patients with viral meningitis is typically normal or only slightly increased; this patient's opening pressure was significantly increased. In addition, viruses cannot be cultured on Sabouraud agar.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of tachyzoites in the CSF confirms a diagnosis of toxoplasmic encephalitis. This condition is caused by reactivation of Toxoplasma gondii in patients who are immunocompromised and can manifest with progressive headache, nausea, fever, and meningism. However, T. gondii cannot grow on Sabouraud agar; diagnostic testing for this organism includes serologic testing, PCR for T. gondii DNA, and histopathologic examination of tissue and/or fluid.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of gram-positive rods in the CSF is seen in patients with bacterial meningitis caused by Listeria monocytogenes. L. monocytogenes meningitis is more common among neonates and adults > 60 years of age but can develop in patients who are immunocompromised. This condition can manifest subacutely with progressive headache, nausea, fever, meningism, and a significantly increased opening pressure on lumbar puncture. However, L. monocytogenes cannot grow on Sabouraud agar; this organism can be cultured on bacterial media such as blood agar.

F) INCORRECT:

An increased adenosine deaminase concentration in the CSF is seen in tuberculous meningitis. This condition can manifest with progressive headache, nausea, fever, meningism, and a significantly increased opening pressure on lumbar puncture. However, Mycobacterium tuberculosis cannot grow on Sabouraud agar; this organism can be cultured on Löwenstein-Jensen agar.

G) INCORRECT:

A positive PCR for JC virus DNA in the CSF confirms a diagnosis of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). This condition is caused by reactivation of the JC virus in patients who are immunocompromised and typically causes focal neurologic deficits (e.g., motor deficits, visual deficits). PML does not typically cause nausea, fever, meningism, or a significantly increased opening pressure on lumbar puncture. In addition, viruses cannot be cultured on Sabouraud agar.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, an opportunistic infection that typically causes progressive fever and meningism over a period of 1–2 weeks.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old military nurse with Crohn disease comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of fever, fatigue, dry cough, headache, and myalgia. During this period, he has also had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss. One week ago, he developed several painful oral lesions and difficulty swallowing. He serves at a military base in Ohio. Current medications include prednisone and infliximab. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), respirations are 20/min, pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 115/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diffuse bilateral crackles, hepatosplenomegaly, and multiple 1–2 cm ulcerative lesions with raised borders in the oral mucosa. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.0 g/dL


Erythrocyte count
3.0 million/mm3



Leukocyte count
4000/mm3 



Platelet count
100,000/mm3



Serum



AST
112 U/L


ALT
96 U/L


Results of a combined HIV antigen/antibody testing and an interferon-γ release assay are negative. An x-ray of the chest shows hilar lymphadenopathy with central calcification and multiple well-defined pulmonary nodules measuring 1–10 mm. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Amphotericin B is the best initial pharmacotherapy for disseminated histoplasmosis. Treatment with amphotericin B is given for 1–2 weeks and then followed by treatment with itraconazole for at least 12 months. For patients who are immunosuppressed and have only mild to moderate symptoms, treatment with itraconazole alone is appropriate. Patients who are immunocompetent typically only develop mild pulmonary disease and can be treated supportively.

Pulmonary findings of histoplasmosis and sarcoidosis can be very similar (e.g., pulmonary nodules, hilar lymphadenopathy). Histoplasmosis should be ruled out in endemic regions before starting corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive drugs if sarcoidosis is suspected.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2015)

B) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is used to treat Legionnaires' disease, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles). However, this condition typically manifests with diffuse interstitial infiltrates, not hilar lymphadenopathy and pulmonary nodules. In addition, Legionnaires' disease does not cause oral ulcers or hepatosplenomegaly. Levofloxacin is not used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is used to treat Pneumocystis pneumonia, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles). However, this condition typically manifests with diffuse interstitial infiltrates, not hilar lymphadenopathy and pulmonary nodules. In addition, Pneumocystis pneumonia does not cause oral ulcers or hepatosplenomegaly. TMP-SMX is not used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Flucytosine, in combination with amphotericin B, is used to treat cryptococcosis, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles, pulmonary nodules). However, this condition does not cause oral ulcers or hepatosplenomegaly. Flucytosine is not used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Caspofungin is used to treat invasive candidiasis, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and liver involvement (e.g., increased serum transaminases). However, this condition does not cause oral ulcers and only rarely affects the lungs. Caspofungin is not used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Voriconazole is a first-line treatment for invasive aspergillosis, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles, pulmonary nodules). However, this condition does not cause oral ulcers or hepatosplenomegaly and only rarely causes hilar lymphadenopathy. Voriconazole is not typically used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.
questions.hint: This patient takes immunosuppressive medications and has nonspecific constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss), oral ulcers, hepatosplenomegaly, pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles, hilar lymphadenopathy, well-defined pulmonary nodules), pancytopenia, and increased transaminase levels. These findings, in combination with living in an area endemic for Histoplasma capsulatum (Ohio), are consistent with a diagnosis of disseminated histoplasmosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of intermittent fevers, productive cough, and shortness of breath. Three weeks ago he was treated with amoxicillin-clavulanate and azithromycin, which did not improve his symptoms. He is also worried because he has noticed “some new bumps on his skin”. He lives in upstate New York along the Mohawk River. He has rheumatoid arthritis. He does not smoke cigarettes. His medications include methotrexate and a multivitamin. His temperature is 38.1ºC (100.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/75 mm Hg. Diffuse crackles are heard over both lung fields. Skin examination shows multiple, white, verrucous papules and nodules on the thighs. A CT scan of the chest shows bilateral tree-in-bud opacities in the lower lobes. A biopsy of a skin nodule shows pyogranulomatous inflammation and round yeast cells. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP pneumonia) is an opportunistic pulmonary infection that manifests with fever, cough, and dyspnea resistant to standard antibiotic treatment, all of which are seen here. However, PCP pneumonia rarely causes cutaneous manifestations. Moreover, PCP pneumonia is almost exclusively seen in immunocompromised patients (e.g., patients with AIDS). A biopsy would show disc-shaped yeast cells rather than round yeast cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungus that causes cryptococcosis, a condition that can manifest as pneumonia with extrapulmonary symptoms (including nodular skin lesions), which this patient has. However, Cryptococcus neoformans primarily affects patients who are immunocompromised (e.g., patients with AIDS). Moreover, Cryptococcus neoformans more commonly causes cryptococcal meningitis, which is not seen here.

C) CORRECT:

Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus endemic to the eastern and central United States that causes blastomycosis. This infection most often affects patients who are immunosuppressed or immunocompromised but, unlike most other dimorphic fungal infections, it can cause disseminated disease even in immunocompetent individuals. Blastomycosis typically manifests as pneumonia with extrapulmonary symptoms, which can involve the skin (e.g., verrucous skin lesions and granulomatous nodules, as seen in this patient), genitourinary system (e.g., prostatitis), central nervous system (e.g., meningitis and brain abscesses), and skeletal system (e.g., osteolytic lesions).

Patients who have pulmonary or extrapulmonary blastomycosis that does not affect the central nervous system can be treated with oral azoles (e.g., itraconazole). Severe infection, including cases in which the central nervous system is involved, should be treated with amphotericin B.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2017)

D) INCORRECT:

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that causes sporotrichosis. Although this condition usually manifests with localized disease, it can cause disseminated disease in patients who are immunosuppressed or immunocompromised. However, sporotrichosis typically develops after a penetrating skin injury (e.g., from a thorn) and manifests with a pustule or ulcer that progresses to ascending lymphangitis; pulmonary involvement is rare.

E) INCORRECT:

Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus endemic to the eastern and central United States that causes (disseminated) histoplasmosis, which can manifest as pneumonia with extrapulmonary symptoms (including nodular skin lesions). However, this condition primarily affects patients who are immunocompromised (e.g., patients with AIDS or transplant recipients). A biopsy would show small yeast cells contained within macrophages.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2015)

F) INCORRECT:

Paracoccidioides lutzii is a dimorphic fungus that causes paracoccidioidomycosis, a systemic fungal infection that classically manifests as pneumonia with extrapulmonary symptoms (including nodular skin lesions), which this patient has. However, this fungus is endemic to Latin America, not the eastern and central United States.

G) INCORRECT:

Aspergillus fumigatus is a fungus that causes pulmonary aspergillosis, a condition that can manifest with fever, cough, and dyspnea, all of which are seen here. However, cutaneous manifestations of aspergillosis are uncommon. Moreover, a biopsy would show a mold, not yeast cells.

H) INCORRECT:

Coccidioides immitis is a dimorphic fungus that causes disseminated coccidioidomycosis, a condition that can manifest as pneumonia with extrapulmonary symptoms (including nodular skin lesions), which this patient has. However, disseminated coccidioidomycosis primarily affects patients who are immunocompromised (e.g., patients with AIDS). Moreover, Coccidioides immitis is endemic to the southwestern United States, not the eastern and central United States.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2017)
questions.hint: This patient has subacute pneumonia that has not improved with antibiotic therapy. His extrapulmonary manifestations (cutaneous lesions), imaging findings (tree-in-bud opacities in the lower lobes), and biopsy findings (round yeast cells) are characteristic of a disseminated infection caused by a fungus endemic to the eastern and central United States. This patient's infection has disseminated even though he is not significantly immunocompromised (at normal doses, methotrexate has immunomodulatory effects but does not result in severe immunosuppression).

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman from New York City comes to the emergency department on Christmas Eve because of a 10-day history of malaise and a progressively worsening headache with occasional nausea and vomiting. She also has had a 6-week history of dyspnea, a productive cough, and night sweats. The patient is accompanied by a 10-year-old boy who says that they initially met while he was walking alone in Central Park and that he found her “covered with pigeons.” The patient does not remember her medical history and denies having traveled anywhere recently. She does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F) and respirations are 25/min. She is alert and fully oriented. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. There is nuchal rigidity. Her CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 80/mm3. An HIV screening test is positive. An MRI of the brain shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely infectious agent?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Slow-onset malaise, low-grade fever, and headache associated with nausea and vomiting, combined with a low CD4+ T-lymphocyte count, should raise concern for cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, an AIDS-defining illness caused by Cryptococcus neoformans that usually occurs only in patients with a CD4+ count < 100 cells/mm3. Cryptococcal meningoencephalitis can develop following an initial pulmonary infection, which may be asymptomatic or manifest as pulmonary cryptococcosis with dyspnea, a productive cough, and night sweats. The fungus is commonly transmitted via soil or pigeon droppings.

In patients with suspected cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, neuroimaging should be performed to rule out mass lesions; MRI findings may include gelatinous pseudocysts of the basal ganglia in some patients. In cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, CSF analysis typically shows increased opening pressure, a lymphocyte-predominant cell count, increased protein concentration, and decreased glucose concentration. The diagnosis can be established by cryptococcal antigen testing and CSF staining with mucicarmine or India ink. Treatment includes intravenous amphotericin B and oral flucytosine.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

B) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) can cause herpes encephalitis, especially in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., those with AIDS). Patients with herpes encephalitis typically have progressive headaches but usually also present with acute neurologic abnormalities such as seizures, behavioral changes, and focal neurologic deficits. MRI of the brain classically shows temporal lobe involvement.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with a 3-day history of headache, nausea, forgetfulness, low-grade fever, and seizures

Cortical and subcortical T2 hyperintensity (green overlay) is demonstrated within the left medial temporal lobe associated with mild gyral expansion. The differential diagnosis included post-ictal changes and viral encephalitides of different origins, with neoplasm and other causes being less likely. PCR of the CSF confirmed the diagnosis of herpes simplex encephalitis.

T: temporal lobe; P: pons; C: cerebellum

C) INCORRECT:

Coccidioides immitis is a dimorphic fungus that causes pulmonary coccidioidomycosis (valley fever), which typically manifests with dyspnea, cough, and night sweats. Immunocompromised individuals (e.g., those with AIDS) can develop coccidioidal meningitis, which causes headache and nausea. However, Coccidioides immitis is endemic to the Southwestern United States, not New York City, and this patient has no known history of recent travel. Moreover, the presence of other common features, such as skin involvement (erythema nodosum or erythema multiforme), would also be expected in a patient with disseminated coccidioidomycosis.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2017)

D) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis jirovecii is a yeast-like fungus that causes Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) in patients with AIDS and a CD4+ count < 200/mm3. PCP classically manifests with cough, low-grade fever, and malaise, and symptoms typically have a gradual onset over days to weeks. However, PCP does not typically cause nuchal rigidity and progressive headaches, and the cough is usually nonproductive.

E) INCORRECT:

Reactivation of latent JC virus infection can cause progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) in patients with AIDS and a CD4+ count < 200 cells/mm3. Patients with PML often have headache and nausea but more commonly present with other acute neurologic abnormalities such as altered mental status, motor deficits, ataxia, and visual deficits. MRI of the brain classically shows disseminated, nonenhancing white matter lesions.
Image Description:

MRI Head (A: T2 weighted, B: T1 weighted with contrast; axial plane)

A T2 hyperintense lesion without mass effect (image A, green overlay) in the left cerebellar hemisphere does not enhance on the T1 weighted sequence (image B). Other enhancing foci (red overlay) are seen in B, although such enhancement is uncommon in PML.

PML lesions typically involve parietooccipital subcortical and periventricular white matter, are T2 hyperintense, do not enhance, and produce little or no mass effect.

F) INCORRECT:

Reactivation of latent Toxoplasma gondii infection can cause cerebral toxoplasmosis in patients with AIDS and a CD4+ count < 100 cells/mm3, and typically manifests with progressive headache and low-grade fever. Moreover, extracerebral manifestations include pulmonary toxoplasmosis, which can cause dyspnea and cough. However, cerebral toxoplasmosis also typically manifests with seizures and focal neurologic deficits, and MRI or CT of the brain classically shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the cerebrum and/or basal ganglia.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with cerebral toxoplasmosis

A small nodule (hatched overlay) in the right internal capsule is accompanied by hyperintense perilesional edema (solid overlay).

Neurotoxoplasmosis more commonly manifests with multiple lesions and it has a propensity for the corticomedullary junction, thalami, and basal ganglia. It is a leading cerebral opportunistic infection in patients with AIDS.
questions.hint: This patient with HIV infection has been in contact with pigeons and has slow-onset features of pneumonia (dyspnea, productive cough) and subacute CNS involvement (worsening headache with nausea and vomiting, nuchal rigidity, and low-grade fever). She also helped the boy escape from the cruel hands of Harry and Marv, two thieves the child encountered last Christmas…

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 48 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I've got this lumpy rash on my arm.”
History of Present Illness:


2-week history of a nonpruritic rash on his left forearm 

began as a pustule close to the wrist; now spreading to the elbow with nodules and ulcers


Past Medical History:
unremarkable
Medications:
none
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known allergies
Family History:
mother and father: alive with no chronic conditions
Psychosocial History:

does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use other substances
gardener
cat owner

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


36.4°C(97.5°F)
72/min
22/min
125/70 mm Hg
-
183 cm(6 ft)
100 kg(220 lb)
30 kg/m2




Appearance: alert; comfortable
Skin: a photograph is shown

Neck: no lymph nodes palpable
Pulmonary: clear lung fields
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Abdominal: nondistended; nontender to palpation
Extremities: left axillary lymphadenopathy



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Superficial thrombophlebitis usually manifests with tenderness, erythema, and induration that spreads along a superficial vein, often with a palpable cord. Superficial thrombophlebitis rarely ulcerates and most commonly affects superficial veins of the leg in patients with varicose veins or risk factors for venous thromboembolism.

B) CORRECT:

Sporotrichosis is associated with traumatic injury to the skin (e.g., a thorn prick) and most commonly occurs in gardeners and landscapers. This condition manifests at the site of traumatic injury with a papule that usually ulcerates or becomes nodular with overlying erythema; it commonly spreads proximally along lymphatic vessels (i.e., ascending lymphangitis). Systemic symptoms only occur in disseminated infections (e.g., in immunocompromised individuals). Oral itraconazole or potassium iodide is the first-line treatment for cutaneous sporotrichosis. Disseminated infections are treated with IV amphotericin B.

C) INCORRECT:

Primary inoculation tuberculosis is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis transmitted via broken skin or mucosa that manifests with a firm, nontender ulcer and lymphadenopathy. However, this condition typically leads to abscess formation and is associated with inadequately sterilized needles (e.g., from a tattoo) or surgical equipment. Additionally, this condition occurs primarily in children in endemic areas.

D) INCORRECT:

Tularemia can be transmitted by arthropod bites (e.g., ticks, deer flies) or by contact with infected animals; therefore, gardeners and those with pets are at risk. Ulceroglandular tularemia manifests with an ulcer and regional lymphadenopathy, as seen here. However, systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, chills, confusion) and a single ulcer at the entry site of the pathogen, rather than numerous nodular lesions along the lymphatic vessels, would be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Cat scratch disease may manifest with a lesion at the initial site of infection and local lymphadenopathy. Additionally, as a cat owner, this patient is at risk. However, the lesion is usually a papule or pustule and rarely ulcerates or forms nodules. Flu-like symptoms (e.g., headache, fever, myalgia) would also be expected.
Image Description:

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.
questions.hint: A biopsy of the lesion would show cigar-shaped buds.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with HIV infection comes to the emergency department because of a 4-week history of progressively worsening fatigue and headache. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). On mental status examination, the patient is somnolent and oriented only to person. Her CD4+ lymphocyte count is 80/mm3. Analysis of this patient's cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows a leukocyte count of 30/mm3 (60% lymphocytes), a protein concentration of 52 mg/dL, and a glucose concentration of 37 mg/dL. An India ink stain of the CSF is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's neurological symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The combination of pyrimethamine, sulfadiazine, and folinic acid is the treatment of choice for cerebral toxoplasmosis in immunocompromised patients. Cerebral toxoplasmosis typically presents with altered mental status, headache, focal neurologic deficits, seizures, and fever. Although this patient has signs and symptoms of CNS infection, and HIV infection, the CSF findings suggest a fungal infection, which makes the diagnosis of cerebral toxoplasmosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

The combination of isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol is used to treat an active Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection, which should be suspected in patients who present with constitutional symptoms and pulmonary symptoms. M. tuberculosis can also spread to the central nervous system and cause tuberculous meningitis, which may present with headache, fever, and an altered mental status, as seen in this patient. While this patient's CSF findings suggest a fungal infection, M. tuberculosis would appear as acid-fast, pink rods on Ziehl-Neelsen stain.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of cefotaxime and ampicillin is used as an empiric treatment for community-acquired meningitis in neonates < 1 month old. Adult patients < 50 years of age should receive an empiric treatment with vancomycin and ceftriaxone. However, this patient has an infection with Cryptococcus neoformans, against which bacterial antibiotics are of no use.

D) CORRECT:

The combination of intravenous amphotericin B and oral flucytosine is used to treat cryptococcal meningitis. This combination is administered during the induction phase to achieve rapid sterilization of the CSF, followed by maintenance therapy with fluconazole. Cryptococcal meningitis can develop following initial respiratory infection and may lead to death within weeks if left untreated.

E) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole monotherapy is indicated for the maintenance therapy of cryptococcal meningitis once the induction phase has been completed. Fluconazole alone is not sufficient to treat active cryptococcal meningitis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fever, headache, and altered mental status, all of which suggests the presence of a CNS infection. Lymphocytic pleocytosis and the detection of a yeast with a prominent halo on Indian ink stain suggest meningitis due to infection with Cryptococcus neoformans.

However, PCP does not typically cause nuchal rigidity and progressive headaches, and the cough is usually nonproductive.

E) INCORRECT:

Reactivation of latent Toxoplasma gondii infection can cause cerebral toxoplasmosis in patients with AIDS and a CD4+ count < 100 cells/mm3, and typically manifests with progressive headache and low-grade fever. Moreover, extracerebral manifestations include pulmonary toxoplasmosis, which can cause dyspnea and cough. However, cerebral toxoplasmosis also typically manifests with seizures and focal neurologic deficits, and MRI or CT of the brain classically shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the cerebrum and/or basal ganglia.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with cerebral toxoplasmosis

A small nodule (hatched overlay) in the right internal capsule is accompanied by hyperintense perilesional edema (solid overlay).

Neurotoxoplasmosis more commonly manifests with multiple lesions and it has a propensity for the corticomedullary junction, thalami, and basal ganglia. It is a leading cerebral opportunistic infection in patients with AIDS.
questions.hint: This patient with HIV infection has been in contact with pigeons and has slow-onset features of pneumonia (dyspnea, productive cough) and subacute CNS involvement (worsening headache with nausea and vomiting, nuchal rigidity, and low-grade fever). She also helped the boy escape from the cruel hands of Harry and Marv, two thieves the child encountered last Christmas…

questions.text: A 35-year-old military nurse with Crohn disease comes to the office because of a 3-week history of fever, fatigue, dry cough, headache, and myalgia. During this period, he has also had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss. One week ago, he developed several painful oral lesions and difficulty swallowing. He serves at a military base in Ohio. Current medications include prednisone and infliximab. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), respirations are 20/min, pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 115/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diffuse bilateral crackles, hepatosplenomegaly, and multiple 1–2 cm ulcerative lesions with raised borders in the oral mucosa. Laboratory studies show pancytopenia and increased transaminase levels. Results of a combined HIV antigen/antibody testing and an interferon-γ release assay are negative. An x-ray of the chest shows hilar lymphadenopathy with central calcification and multiple well-defined pulmonary nodules measuring 1–10 mm. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Amphotericin B is the best initial pharmacotherapy for disseminated histoplasmosis. Treatment with amphotericin B is given for 1–2 weeks and then followed by treatment with itraconazole for at least 12 months. For patients who are immunosuppressed and have only mild to moderate symptoms, treatment with itraconazole alone is appropriate. Patients who are immunocompetent typically only develop mild pulmonary disease and can be treated supportively.

Pulmonary findings of histoplasmosis and sarcoidosis can be very similar (e.g., pulmonary nodules, hilar lymphadenopathy). Histoplasmosis should be ruled out in endemic regions before starting corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive drugs if sarcoidosis is suspected.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2015)

B) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is used to treat Legionnaires' disease, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles). However, this condition typically manifests with diffuse interstitial infiltrates, not hilar lymphadenopathy and pulmonary nodules. In addition, Legionnaires' disease does not cause oral ulcers or hepatosplenomegaly. Levofloxacin is not used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is used to treat Pneumocystis pneumonia, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles). However, this condition typically manifests with diffuse interstitial infiltrates, not hilar lymphadenopathy and pulmonary nodules. In addition, Pneumocystis pneumonia does not cause oral ulcers or hepatosplenomegaly. TMP-SMX is not used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Caspofungin is used to treat invasive candidiasis, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and liver involvement (e.g., increased serum transaminases). However, this condition does not cause oral ulcers and only rarely affects the lungs. Caspofungin is not used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Voriconazole is a first-line treatment for invasive aspergillosis, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles, pulmonary nodules). However, this condition does not cause oral ulcers or hepatosplenomegaly and only rarely causes hilar lymphadenopathy. Voriconazole is not typically used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.
questions.hint: This patient takes immunosuppressive medications and has nonspecific constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss), oral ulcers, hepatosplenomegaly, pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles, hilar lymphadenopathy, well-defined pulmonary nodules), pancytopenia, and increased transaminase levels. These findings, in combination with living in an area endemic for Histoplasma capsulatum (Ohio), are consistent with a diagnosis of disseminated histoplasmosis.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the office by his father because of a progressively worsening rash on his buttocks for the last week. He cries during diaper changes and is more fussy than usual. Physical examination of the boy shows erythematous papules and plaques in the bilateral inguinal creases, on the scrotum, and in the gluteal cleft. Small areas of maceration are also present. A diagnosis is made, and treatment with topical clotrimazole is initiated. Microscopic examination of skin scrapings from this patient's rash is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Fruiting bodies with septate, acute-angle hyphae
Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Narrow budding, encapsulated yeast on India ink staining indicates Cryptococcus neoformans infection. Cryptococcus neoformans infection is primarily seen in immunocompromised patients and can cause pneumonia, cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, and brain abscesses. Cryptococcus neoformans is not associated with diaper rash.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

B) CORRECT:

Candida albicans appears as oval, budding yeast with pseudohyphae in skin scrapings of an infection. Candida albicans is part of the normal skin flora, but infection can occur when there is an imbalance that allows local Candida albicans overgrowth. Infants are often affected by Candida mucocutaneous infections in the anogenital region since overgrowth is facilitated by the prolonged damp and warm conditions of a diaper.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (200x magnification)

A cluster of yeast-like cells (arrowhead) is visible in the upper right corner of the image. Arising from this cluster are numerous pseudohyphae identifiable as long filamentous nonseptate structures (example indicated by a blue overlay). Asexual budding spores (blastospores; example indicated by red overlay) arise along the sides of the pseudohyphae. Thick-walled solitary circular chlamydospores (resting stage of Candida; example indicated by green overlay) arise from the tips of the pseudohyphae.

This coexistence of different morphological types (yeast cells, pseudohyphae, budding blastospores, and resting chlamydospores) is typical of Candida albicans.

C) INCORRECT:

Fruiting bodies with septate, acute-angle hyphae (45°) on tissue biopsy indicate Aspergillus fumigatus infection. Aspergillus fumigatus can cause allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), chronic pulmonary aspergillosis, invasive aspergillosis, and infective endocarditis. Although Aspergillus fumigatus can cause irritation of the skin in patients with ABPA, it is not associated with diaper rash.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Aspergillus fumigatus

Several buds are visible sprouting from the thread-like structure of the septate hyphae (green overlays). Buds are composed of a stalk (conidiophore; blue overlay) topped by a conidial head. The head consists of a central spherical vesicle (not visible here but indicated by yellow circle) surrounded by chains of prophialide (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and phialide projections (examples indicated by green arrowheads) with conidia tips (examples indicated by black arrowheads). The base is formed by a foot cell (red overlay).

D) INCORRECT:

Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells (captain's wheel) on KOH test (potassium hydroxide smear) indicates Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection is most often asymptomatic, but it can manifest with acute pneumonia, painful nasopharyngeal ulcerations, and verrucous skin lesions. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is not associated with diaper rash.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (methenamine silver stain)

A circular cell with round budding daughter cells can be seen in the center of the image. This appearance (“pilot's wheel”) is characteristic of Paracoccidioides species. Additional Paracoccidioides cells that do not have the classic appearance can be seen in the upper left.

E) INCORRECT:

Broad-based budding yeast on KOH test (potassium hydroxide smear) indicates Blastomyces dermatitidis infection. This patient has a diaper rash and no evidence of systemic disease (e.g., pneumonia, flulike symptoms), making a Blastomyces dermatitidis infection highly unlikely.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (GMS stain)

Thick-walled fungi with single broad-based buds are visible.

This is the typical appearance of Blastomyces dermatitidis in yeast form (at body temperature, 37°C). At room temperature (∼ 23°C ), this dimorphic fungus exists in mold form.
questions.hint: This patient has typical signs of a diaper rash due to Candida albicans. It can be treated with a variety of topical antifungal agents such as clotrimazole.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-day history of fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, cough, and chest pain. Physical examination shows diffuse inspiratory crackles over the left lung field. An x-ray of the chest shows hilar lymphadenopathy and well-defined nodules with central calcifications. Urine studies show the presence of a polysaccharide antigen. A biopsy specimen of the lung shows cells with basophilic, crescent-shaped nuclei and pericellular halos located within macrophages. This patient's history is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treatment with inhaled glucocorticoids is an important risk factor for developing thrush (oropharyngeal infection with Candida albicans). This condition is not associated with pneumonia, lymphadenopathy, or the biopsy and antigen findings seen in this case. In addition, the characteristic lesions of thrush are white, oropharyngeal patches that show budding yeast and pseudohyphae on KOH preparation, not intracellular organisms.
Image Description:

Typical rod-like, budding structure of Candida albicans (red overlay).

B) INCORRECT:

A recent visit to the Arizona desert is a risk factor for infection with Coccidioides immitis, a dimorphic fungus endemic to the deserts of the southwestern United States, Mexico, and Central and South America. Pulmonary coccidioidomycosis (valley fever) can cause symptoms of acute pneumonia and manifest with lymphadenopathy on chest x-ray, which is seen here. However, it does not explain the antigen findings seen in this case. Additional manifestations of coccidioidomycosis would include arthralgia (“desert rheumatism”) and erythema nodosum or multiforme (“desert bumps”), which this patient does not have. Finally, microscopic evaluation of a biopsy would show spherules containing endospores, not intracellular organisms.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Coccidioides immitis in lung tissue (methenamine silver stain; high magnification)

Spherule (red circles) and endospore (green overlays) forms of Coccidioides immitis, a causative agent of coccidioidomycosis, can be seen.

C) INCORRECT:

A recent trip to Brazil is a risk factor for infection with Paracoccidioides spp., a dimorphic fungus endemic to South and Central America. Paracoccidioidomycosis causes pneumonia but not the antigen findings seen in this case. Additional manifestations include mucosal ulcerations and cervical (not hilar) lymphadenopathy. Biopsy would show budding yeast with a captain's wheel appearance, not intracellular organisms.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (methenamine silver stain)

A circular cell with round budding daughter cells can be seen in the center of the image. This appearance (“pilot's wheel”) is characteristic of Paracoccidioides species. Additional Paracoccidioides cells that do not have the classic appearance can be seen in the upper left.

D) INCORRECT:

Previous mycobacterial infection is a risk factor for pulmonary aspergillosis (aspergilloma) due to colonization of pre-existing lung cavities by inhaled Aspergillus spores. Pulmonary aspergillosis can manifest with fever, cough, and respiratory distress but would be unlikely to cause calcified nodules, hilar lymphadenopathy, or the antigen findings seen in this case. In addition, biopsy of affected tissue would show acute-angle septate hyphae on staining, not intracellular organisms.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

There are numerous elongated, septated hyphae (examples indicated by blue overlay) of uniform diameter and with dichotomous branching at approx. 45° angles.

This is the typical appearance of Aspergillus. A culture is required to determine the exact Aspergillus species.

E) CORRECT:

Bat and bird droppings can carry Histoplasma capsulatum, particularly in endemic areas (e.g., the Ohio and Mississippi river valleys). Inhalation of the fungus causes histoplasmosis, a condition that manifests with primary pulmonary disease or disseminated disease, especially in patients who are immunocompromised.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue specimen (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Intracellular (examples indicated by white arrowheads) and extracellular (examples indicated by black arrowheads) forms of ovoid yeast-like organisms are visible.

The presence of these organisms is indicative of histoplasmosis. Diagnosis must be confirmed by culture and PCR array to determine the exact species (Histoplasma capsulatum in this case).
questions.hint: This woman has pneumonia (fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, cough, chest pain, crackles), hilar lymphadenopathy, a polysaccharide antigen in the urine, and a biopsy specimen of the lung that shows yeast cells within macrophages, all of which are features of Histoplasma capsulatum infection.

questions.text: You are seeing a 40-year-old woman with HIV infection who presents to the emergency department with a 4-week history of progressively worsening fatigue and headache. Her temperature is 38.1°C. On mental status examination, she is somnolent and oriented only to person. Her CD4+ lymphocyte count is 0.08 × 109/L (0.8–3.3). Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows a leukocyte count of 30/mm3 (60% lymphocytes), protein concentration of 0.52 g/L, and glucose concentration of 2.1 mmol/L. An India ink stain of the CSF is provided. Which one of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for her neurological symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole monotherapy is indicated for the maintenance therapy of cryptococcal meningitis once the induction phase has been completed. Fluconazole alone is not sufficient to treat active cryptococcal meningitis.

B) INCORRECT:

The combination of pyrimethamine, sulfadiazine, and folinic acid is the treatment of choice for cerebral toxoplasmosis in immunocompromised patients. Cerebral toxoplasmosis typically presents with altered mental status, headache, focal neurologic deficits, seizures, and fever. Although this patient has signs and symptoms of CNS infection, and HIV infection, the CSF findings suggest a fungal infection, which makes the diagnosis of cerebral toxoplasmosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of cefotaxime and ampicillin is used as an empiric treatment for community-acquired meningitis in neonates < 1 month old. Adult patients < 50 years of age should receive an empiric treatment with vancomycin and ceftriaxone. However, this patient has an infection with Cryptococcus neoformans, against which bacterial antibiotics are of no use.

D) INCORRECT:

The combination of isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol is used to treat an active Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection, which should be suspected in patients who present with constitutional symptoms and pulmonary symptoms. M. tuberculosis can also spread to the central nervous system and cause tuberculous meningitis, which may present with headache, fever, and an altered mental status, as seen in this patient. While this patient's CSF findings suggest a fungal infection, M. tuberculosis would appear as acid-fast, pink rods on Ziehl-Neelsen stain.

E) CORRECT:

The combination of intravenous amphotericin B and oral flucytosine is used to treat cryptococcal meningitis. This combination is administered during the induction phase to achieve rapid sterilization of the CSF, followed by maintenance therapy with fluconazole. Cryptococcal meningitis can develop following initial respiratory infection and may lead to death within weeks if left untreated.

Key learning point: Initial treatment of cryptococcal meningitis in HIV patients requires induction therapy with intravenous amphotericin B plus oral flucytosine, followed by maintenance therapy with fluconazole.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fever, headache, and altered mental status, all of which suggests the presence of a CNS infection. Lymphocytic pleocytosis and the detection of a yeast with a prominent halo on Indian ink stain suggest meningitis due to infection with Cryptococcus neoformans.

Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (200x magnification)

Arising from this cluster are numerous pseudohyphae identifiable as long filamentous nonseptate structures (example indicated by a blue overlay). questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-day history of fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, cough, and chest pain. On examination, there are diffuse inspiratory crackles over the left lung field. Chest x-ray shows hilar lymphadenopathy and well-defined nodules with central calcifications. Urine studies reveal a polysaccharide antigen. Lung biopsy shows cells with basophilic, crescent-shaped nuclei and pericellular halos within macrophages. Which one of the following is most likely to be found in her history?

A) INCORRECT:

A recent visit to the Arizona desert is a risk factor for infection with Coccidioides immitis, a dimorphic fungus endemic to the deserts of the southwestern United States, Mexico, and Central and South America. Pulmonary coccidioidomycosis (valley fever) can cause symptoms of acute pneumonia and manifest with lymphadenopathy on chest x-ray, which is seen here. However, it does not explain the antigen findings seen in this case. Additional manifestations of coccidioidomycosis would include arthralgia (“desert rheumatism”) and erythema nodosum or multiforme (“desert bumps”), which this patient does not have. Finally, microscopic evaluation of a biopsy would show spherules containing endospores, not intracellular organisms.

Treatment with inhaled glucocorticoids is an important risk factor for developing thrush (oropharyngeal infection with Candida albicans). This condition is not associated with pneumonia, lymphadenopathy, or the biopsy and antigen findings seen in this case. In addition, the characteristic lesions of thrush are white, oropharyngeal patches that show budding yeast and pseudohyphae on KOH preparation, not intracellular organisms.

C) INCORRECT:

A recent trip to Brazil is a risk factor for infection with Paracoccidioides spp., a dimorphic fungus endemic to South and Central America. Paracoccidioidomycosis causes pneumonia but not the antigen findings seen in this case. Additional manifestations include mucosal ulcerations and cervical (not hilar) lymphadenopathy. Biopsy would show budding yeast with a captain's wheel appearance, not intracellular organisms.

Previous mycobacterial infection is a risk factor for pulmonary aspergillosis (aspergilloma) due to colonization of pre-existing lung cavities by inhaled Aspergillus spores. Pulmonary aspergillosis can manifest with fever, cough, and respiratory distress but would be unlikely to cause calcified nodules, hilar lymphadenopathy, or the antigen findings seen in this case. In addition, biopsy of affected tissue would show acute-angle septate hyphae on staining, not intracellular organisms.

Bat and bird droppings can carry Histoplasma capsulatum, particularly in endemic areas (e.g., the Ohio and Mississippi river valleys). Inhalation of the fungus causes histoplasmosis, a condition that manifests with primary pulmonary disease or disseminated disease, especially in patients who are immunocompromised.

Key learning point: Histoplasmosis is commonly acquired by inhaling spores from bat or bird droppings, especially in the Ohio and Mississippi river valleys.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue specimen (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Intracellular (examples indicated by white arrowheads) and extracellular (examples indicated by black arrowheads) forms of ovoid yeast-like organisms are visible.

The presence of these organisms is indicative of histoplasmosis. Diagnosis must be confirmed by culture and PCR array to determine the exact species (Histoplasma capsulatum in this case).
questions.hint: This woman has pneumonia (fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, cough, chest pain, crackles), hilar lymphadenopathy, a polysaccharide antigen in the urine, and a biopsy specimen of the lung that shows yeast cells within macrophages, all of which are features of Histoplasma capsulatum infection.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of fever, night sweats, malaise, dyspnea, and a productive cough with bloody sputum for 4 days. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 15 years ago and has not been adherent with his medication regimen. Physical examination shows diminished breath sounds over the left lung fields. An x-ray of the chest shows an ill-defined lesion in the upper lobe of the left lung. A CT-guided biopsy of the lesion is performed; a photomicrograph of the biopsy specimen stained with mucicarmine is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coccidioides immitis infections cause coccidioidomycosis, a fungal infection that is often asymptomatic but can manifest with fever, cough, and malaise. However, methenamine silver staining would reveal spherules filled with endospores. Furthermore, C. immitis does not have a polysaccharide capsule, so it does not stain with mucicarmine.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Coccidioides immitis in lung tissue (methenamine silver stain; high magnification)

Spherule (red circles) and endospore (green overlays) forms of Coccidioides immitis, a causative agent of coccidioidomycosis, can be seen.

B) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans is a fungus that may affect the lungs in cases of severe immunosuppression, which manifests with fever, malaise, dyspnea, and cough. KOH staining would show budding yeasts with hyphae and pseudohyphae. However, since C. albicans does not have a polysaccharide capsule, it does not stain with mucicarmine.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of fungus germination (KOH preparation, 600x)

Mother cells (blastospores; green overlay) produce a hyphal outgrowth of germ tubes (budding; dashed red outline).

Budding is suggestive of active candida infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis jirovecii causes pneumocystis pneumonia. P. jirovecii is commonly associated with immunodeficiency (e.g., AIDS), manifests with cough, fever, and malaise, and is visible on silver staining as disc-shaped cysts with central spores. It does not possess a polysaccharide capsule, so it does not stain with mucicarmine.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of alveolar tissue infected with P. jirovecii (Grocott's methenamine silver stain, high magnification)

The cysts of this fungus are located within the alveoli together with an inflammatory exudate (red overlay). The cyst walls are stained black in this silver stain.

D) INCORRECT:

Histoplasma capsulatum is a fungus that can cause histoplasmosis in immunocompromised patients. While histoplasmosis often remains asymptomatic, it can manifest as a flu-like illness, with fever, weight loss, erythema nodosum, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and a nonproductive cough. H. capsulatum stains with either silver, Giemsa, or PAS (showing ovoid yeast), not with the narrow-spectrum mucicarmine used here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue specimen (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Intracellular (examples indicated by white arrowheads) and extracellular (examples indicated by black arrowheads) forms of ovoid yeast-like organisms are visible.

The presence of these organisms is indicative of histoplasmosis. Diagnosis must be confirmed by culture and PCR array to determine the exact species (Histoplasma capsulatum in this case).

E) INCORRECT:

Infection with Blastomyces dermatitidis can cause pneumonia, which is seen in this patient. On staining, B. dermatitidis appears as a multinucleated yeast that forms broad-based buds. However, because it has a thin mucopolysaccharide layer, mucicarmine stains B. dermatitidis light red.

F) CORRECT:

Cryptococcus neoformans is a pathogenic fungus that has a thick polysaccharide capsule, which causes it to stain bright red with mucicarmine. India ink is another dye commonly used to stain C. neoformans. The ink is considered a negative dye; it does not penetrate the polysaccharide capsule of C. neoformans and it leaves a light halo around the fungus. The fungus is primarily transmitted via soil or pigeon droppings and initially infects the respiratory tract. Infection is typically asymptomatic, but cryptococcosis may occur, especially in immunodeficient individuals (e.g., with AIDS). Cryptococcosis usually manifests as isolated pneumonia, and can also manifest as cryptococcal meningoencephalitis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (mucicarmine stain; high magnification)

A widened alveolar septum with inflammatory cell infiltration (white arrowheads: macrophages; black arrowhead: neutrophil granulocyte) and yeasts of Cryptococcus neoformans (green overlay) are visible.

These findings are typical of pulmonary cryptococcosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Aspergillus fumigatus infections cause aspergillosis, which can manifest with pneumonia. H&E, silver, or PAS staining of A. fumigatus would show septate hyphae with fruiting bodies branching at 45° angles. A. fumigatus does not possess a mucin capsule, so it does not stain with mucicarmine.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

There are numerous elongated, septated hyphae (examples indicated by blue overlay) of uniform diameter and with dichotomous branching at approx. 45° angles.

This is the typical appearance of Aspergillus. A culture is required to determine the exact Aspergillus species.
questions.hint: This immunocompromised (HIV) patient has pneumonia (fever, night sweats, malaise, dyspnea, a productive cough with bloody sputum, diminished breath sounds, and lesions on x-ray). The photomicrograph shows ovoid yeast and some narrow-necked budding. Mucicarmine is a narrow-spectrum stain used to identify one particular fungal organism with a thick polysaccharide capsule.
